values:
I wrote a Malay poem tonight. Literally translated as "A Stirred Heart". Thought of sharing. I am going to extend this entry with its English equivalent in a few days' time. Maybe prior to that, someone would like to help come up with its translation. You can be creative, up to your interpretation.
* * * A building somewhere in Seremban, Malaysia. Hati Yang Terusik by Vincent Lai di celah-celah mindaku terpautnya cebisan kata-katanya, yang masih menyelubungi fikiranku yang kusut. aku lalai, pintu hatiku yang lama tertutup, tiba-tiba terbuka, terusik oleh isi hatinya. mentari yang menyinari kamar seolah-olah mengasihaniku. sinar bulan sabit yang lemah bagaikan sindiran yang cemuh. merana aku sehari terusik aku sepanjang malam, dicemari keluhan hati di setiap pelusuk diri. *** A Stirred Heart by Vincent Lai Translated into English from a Malay poem, "Hati Yang Terusik" 1354H, 30 April 2007. between the corners of my mind still bounded by traces of his words, shrouding my clouded thoughts. the careless me; once a long closed heart, its doors suddenly left ajar, stirred by his innermost voice. the rays of the sun that made way into the chamber, as if took pity on me. that faint glow of the moon crescent, as if a laughing stock. for a day I was in despair the whole night disturbed I was, poisoned by the sighs of the heart that infected my every part.

// Cousin Sister @ Bedok Jetty //
Came back from seeing my elder cousin sister, Wei Ling off for her flight to KL at Changi Airport. Might be the last time in two years I will be seeing her as she will be flying off to Cambodia this Friday where she will be based. She treated me to Fish & Co with the seafood platter for two order, and Caesar's salad with smoked salmon. For the first time, we talked on matters related to her family as usually we'd just have pep talks about work, travelling and general things. I briefly questioned her on her boyfriend's thought of her going away for that long. I mean, I can not imagine being away from someone I love for that long and pardon the cold feet for some, I had been in a long distance relationship and it was quite a challenge. And I am not the first who asked her that. She didn't really give me an explanation, but I think she will be fine. Long distance relationship pursuers out there, be strong for love!
// Cousin Sister @ East Coast Beach //
Wei Ling appreciated the time I spent with her throughout her stay in Singapore. Even though I didn't meet her everyday, at least I tried bringing her around trying out different Singapore food. I believe I managed to convince her that the food here is not that bad. Singapore is not just about shopping, as she realised that there are nice places around, such as the previous Sunday, I brought her to the East Coast Park where we went cycling for 2 hours, all the way to the Safra Resort near Tanah Merah Ferry Terminal. Just as she waved at me after clearing the immigration checkpoint, I gave her a faint smile and waved back, pacing my steps slowly and finally walked down to the bus stop. I'm going to miss those short rendezvous with her. Those are the only time I ever converse in full fledge Hokkien dialect in the 2 years of my stay in Singapore. Tomorrow is a new chapter in my life. After a hiatus from work, I'm finally starting the training with my new company. And I have a LJ friend for a colleague. How interesting that is gonna be?!

Looking out of my room window instantly returned cheers to my otherwise ruined earlier half of the day as I received some unpleasant text messages and missed calls from the 22-year old Thai I used to go out with, and having had to spend more money to replace some parts of my laptop which malfunctioned. Never mind them, browsing the pictures my friends sent me not too long ago brought back the nostalgia of my recent trip once again.
// The window view from my room this evening //
The peak of the trip back to my hometown of KL, Malaysia was achieved in a single day in Malacca; a town I'm less than familiar, a richly historical place no less. It was a pep talk with my best friend, Looi whom I have known since we were 7 which brought us to this growing town just one and a half hours drive away from the city of Kuala Lumpur. Monday night, on the second day of the Lunar New Year, Looi was grumbling about his boredom at home and how it got to a point where chatting and working on his MBA assignment were the only ways to pass time. A couple of days earlier, he was suggesting that we drove somewhere out of the city; like Ipoh, Georgetown or even, Segamat. There I was, suddenly thought of an idea of visiting my other best friend, neuy stuck in his hometown. And seizing the opportunity to visit the town of Malacca since my last trip there, way back in 2005, I talked Looi into going there instead, over other far flung choices. I called neuy the next day, in the morning before we left KL to relay the news he was delighted to hear. Actually, I sort of told him about the possibility of the visit the night before, when I was still in the middle of selling the idea to Looi. So I suppose it didn't come as a surprise. Waiting for Looi to get ready and when he finally reached my place, I asked him to our place because mum prepared tang yuen, which is a kind of dessert; flour balls with either red bean paste, sesame paste or peanut fillings in sweet, ginger soup. I asked mum to help prepare a bag of goodies (usually containing Mandarin oranges; which symbolise good luck, and other food stuff) as a visiting gift for neuy's family. We had a good start to the journey down south on the North-South highway with smooth traffic all the way in contrast to the opposite side of the road with occasional crawl. Could be the city folks returning back to KL from their hometown. Along the way, Looi, albeit with the driving, cannot but help texting his girl friends in Malacca, wondering if they were available with my help on the keys. He entrusted me with those deeds. Finally we reached the Ayer Keroh Exit, which led to a mild traffic jam after the toll. I called neuy to confirm the place of meeting which quaintly is a little hawker place next to Hotel Grand Continental, that only comes alive a night. Upon reaching there, we were introduced to totoro2006. I had no idea neuy was planning on bringing a guest. Nevertheless it was a good surprise. Actually totoro2006 was there to visit our celebrated graduate from Dublin too and he turns out to be quite entertaining and accommodating. That, together with the goofy nature of Looi got us all acquainted quite effortlessly. We were headed for lunch, momentarily reminded by the rumbling noises of our tummy. While Looi and totoro2006 were behind the wheels with neuy in the latter's car, while I in Looi's, I called up neuy on his mobile in a smatter of German and English as I was intrigued to find out more about his "new friend", to which I found out later on they got to know each other for some time already. We parked our cars at this little plot near the old wharf by the Malacca River. 3 ringgit for a day's parking seems pretty reasonable but it won't be pleasant when we get back to our seats later on with the scorching sun on the bare car tops. We stopped by this dessert shop not far away, supposedly good according to the guys. Was my first time trying out the cendol (a dessert rich in palm sugar) there and we collectively agreed that we have to try that first! Having no expectations to its reputation, and since the day was o' too hot to be too fussy, I suppose it tasted great. Having said that, however, I have tried a better one in Penang.
// The many faces of neuy //
Moving on for lunch, after a short debate over which chicken rice shop to pick, we finally agreed on Hoe Kee Chicken Rice Restaurant situated near Heeren House, at 4 Jonkers Walk. The night before, guynxtdoor recommended the very same one. We've decided that the one with the longer queue gets our vote. And so there we went queuing up for our share of the famed chicken rice ball. Wondering how it got its name? Well, apparently someone decided to be funny and rather than serving rice from a bowl, they rolled it the size and shape of ping pong balls. While queing up, I was treated to a display of verbal attacks from the newly formed duo of Looi and neuy. They make good partners in crime, said neuy but I was willingly being the subject of all the bitching as it's rare for my two best buddies, myself and totoro2006 to come together, in of all places, Malacca.
// Looi, constantly on the phone // // What's left on the table //
// Us in Pairs //

Wrote another photo-accompanying poem for my friend again after a lapse of one week he asked me to write it. Like a collaboration kind of work. I tend to have this habit of procrastinating when I'm not inspired right away. But today, the inspiration is back. Must be the kid in me coming out, as I'm heading back home to KL for the Lunar New Year celebration with my family and friends there. HAPPY LUNAR NEW YEAR everyone!
* * * The Innocence Of Youth by Vincent Lai The eyes, the nose, the mouth the facial lines of expression the embodiment to human emotions. the child clasping to his mum as his eyes wander innocently amidst the shambles of his hut. the purest nature of expression only a child can own up to for he never hides from his basic right; his feelings. the child can ignore the pains of truth and be just contented, be secured in the embrace of his beloved. that life is a beauty we can live witnessing and embracing the innocence of youth all over again.

Perhaps it is too difficult to interpret. But these are the very words that came out of my head and reflected my momentary emotions. Some friends told me my poems are too cryptic to understand. Maybe I don't want to be understood, just heard. Perhaps the accompanying picture which I shot a couple of days ago at some back alley in Chinatown will speak more than the poem itself.
* * * The Back Seat by Vincent Lai Behind the winged rider thrilled he is not. Behind the vexed heart the pillion rider aches inside. As if so much in common they prided. As if so much in vain they tried. Tonight an idiot he was called; in the spur of an activity. Tonight he became someone else; from whom he was a dear one. As if so much there was it becomes insignificant. As if so much there is it is now a void. Behind the eyes of his the light dims. Behind the mind of his he wants to put behind. As if the storm is gone there is now a dry spell. As if the war is over there is now a looming threat.

Wrote a poem for a friend who requested for it to go with a photo he took of a pink rose, posted on his Flickr site. To maintain discretion, I will not feature his full name. He asked only to use his moniker, EKoan.
* * * Behold Beauty! by Vincent Lai Behold the petals of joy in the caressing light, humbled by the drops of character they bloom into a subject of beauty.

Wake Up And Smell The Reality by Vincent Lai Some people say, "Time heals it all" But you, you just see stars; hiding behind the grey, when it's so clearly black and white. It's time, time to rise from the shades of blue, time to embrace the red, green or yellow, the hues of life that was once you. Wake up and smell the reality Stop clinging on to the loss, stop chasing the wind and start walking This path is yours, and yours only. // For the lost souls out there //
"my door is wide open, with a warm glass of milk in hand, a cosy quilt and bed ready for that someone who accepts all of me" by Vincent Lai

You only need to pay 14 bucks to kiss in front of Tom Cruise and Maggie Q. I was mentally prepared for an exciting film this evening but little did I expect that I'd be blessed with not one but two dramas unfolded right before my very eyes. Complete with lips-sucking sound effect to orchestrate the rest of the performance. So I thought that Gavin and I would have a comfortable view from a priviledged last row to optimise our movie experience. I had this troubling gut instinct when I sat before this dark-skinned couple, presumedly, ethnically Indian; the guy was wrapped around the girl like they were inseparable. How loving, I thought as I looked at them with a dash of envy. Mission Impossible 3 started out bold with Tom Cruise playing Ethan Hunt, clutched to a seat threatened by his villain pointing the gun to his wife's head in scene number one. How I wished those two in front were put to test like that! Would these 2 subjects sacrifice themselves trying to save the other? Judging from back to back intensed kissing and skillful manoeuvre of positions by the female subject on the male subject, I might say yes. But wait, the drama didn't just revolve around kissing. They must make their money's worth and ours by putting up another act. It's called I-need-to-go-fix-my-fanny business. Or, I-need-to-fix-my-willy episode. How brilliant! Twice in the middle of a thrilling Zhen aka Maggie Q does Ferrari scene. By the time the movie credits came up, they finally realised, "Oh, those two behind saw us do all that?".

There are times when you thought you were ready and things just never seem to work out the way you want them to. At other times when you are just not ready and everything just pours in like a burst dam. "Why such irony?"
* * *
When in doubt, we tend to ask people wiser than us for answers. For guidance. More often than not, they won't give them away. It's comforting, yes, to have someone to listen to all your problems. At the end of it, they give in, and ask you to try this and that. "Such standards eh?!" When your mind is at its clearest and when you thought you have conquered the world, you often question the impossible. That's when problems arise, when clearly, you will utterly lose your balance risking to find answers you may not be pleased with. "Thought so, no?" These implications, with such wide profounding notions are related. And usually, they deal with matters at heart. You'd hate to swallow the idea of a long distance relationship based on trust and faith, which by far was all too perfect until you take away the distance. You'd dismiss petty problems until they got blown out of proportion and then you realised, "It's too late". You'd listened to your friends telling you what not to do, and then regretted that it wasn't modelled for you.
* * *
Do people who treat you well have personal agendas in their heads?

A decaying block along an alleyway near Everton Road. Jan 2006
The Agonising Fears by Vincent Lai Winter rain shed its cold, temporal pain; nature does its wonders all over again. The sun, its brief, monogamous warmth; we crave daylight like it's never here. At a time, unabated by the passing phase; I stand through a rush of hopes. Spring of hopes and fears, I'm undecided and scared!

It's here. I'm so happy some of my good friends remembered. I apologise I haven't been able to catch up with you guys for ages. I have recently moved to a new place for the second time. I am already missing the east of Singapore. Marine Parade is such a great neighbourhood to live in. And difficult to find an affordable place to rent there too. Nevertheless, I have to live somewhere close to work sites. In the end, I settled for Spottiswoode Park area. Quite a quaint but pleasant neighbourhood, which I realised after a week living here. Being so close to Chinatown, food is never a problem. Hope to do features on this area in the near future. Featured with this entry is my most recent picture taken 2 months ago on a cycling trip in Pulau Ubin. To commemorate my 26th birthday, I attempted on a haiku entitled "Turning 26". It may not even be haiku because I'm not familiar with the haiku format at all. Pardon my ignorance. Take it with a pinch of salt. Feedbacks are welcomed :)
Turning 26 by Vincent Lai In bed, resting, counting, far away from hometown. 6-month old clock, a faithful wake-up buddy through time, telling time. Bed full, of cards and papers, reminisces of work and kin. Trusting black wallet, of receipts and notes, heaps of vice and kind. A lit tealight, just burning the last strides of the last hour. The darkened screen of cellphone, moments from flashing reminders of age. Up on the ceiling, I looked, churning fantasies of bright future. Cool air, blowing in the new room now my home.

Came home from work today totally exhausted and drained. Simon, my Singaporean flatmate was lying on the couch and just as I greeted him, he brought good news. "Vince, you've got mail!" Simon exclaimed in a more cheerful than yesterday's expression. It's my last month staying in this flat. I have to move by end of the month. I've had 4 wonderful months here. It's such a pity this place has to be returned to the owners at the end of the lease. All of us have to move before 15 Jan, but I chose to move earlier. Simon, the main tenant has found a place in Yishun. Karen, my other flatmate has moved a month earlier just before her month long holiday in Taiwan. I don't know about James, though. Nested with mails of others' is a square sized white envelope with a 47p postmarked stamp, which felt a little thicker than the rest. It's an early Christmas card from a good friend. At the bottom left hand corner of the card is his signature paw print. I smiled a bit reading the message and, from the tone and the strokes of his handwriting I could tell he was really looking forward to the coming year. "Dearest Vincent, here is to you having a very Merry Christmas & a fantastic New Year =) And it's the year of the Woofie too! Woohoo!" I'm really grateful receiving his card today. It made me extra happier than the other days of the week. Thanks Woofie! I have some surprises prepared for my friends who gave me their addresses. I hope I can get them sent before Christmas. Hope those surprises bring fond memories.

More than 2 months since I last updated. It was Yuen; neuy who dug me out of my sink hole, buried by the sands of time at the mercy of work. Not a pretty scene, considering the fact that I gained 5 kilos in such short time without my usual squash sessions and swimming. A healthier diet didn't help much. My free time was spent on catching up with sleep and rest, and spending more quality time with a couple of friends and my lover. It was Yuen, today; in the wee hours of the morning, tempted me with his latest photo of rotten Fuji apples which prompted me to respond with a poem that I have decided to call "The Neuy Hymns", named after him. *grins* I have many times tried to write or post something but the lack of motivation and inspiration just left me struggling for space, time and support. For that little means to write again, I salvaged what's left of me, and here I am taking a little step at one time to face the audience - you; avid readers of my blog, passer-bys, and friends.
The Neuy Hymns by Vincent Lai Just when I thought I can go on rotting away my days at work, you came Just when I thought I had been striked out of the list, you sat next to me Just when I thought everyone had given up on their passion, you bore fruits of hope to feed the lost Just when I thought you stopped time, you wound back the clocks and freed me.

Continuation from Life in Tiong Bahru [ Pt. I ] Just when you start thinking that there is not much to do or discover in your neighbourhood, picture this. A walk to the nearest community centre to be part of some interesting activities. Even sitting down on the bench under a tree, reading your favourite book could be quite a relaxing experience. Going an extra mile, to the nearby recreational place; having a picnic next to Lakeside in the west, playing kites in the East Coast, taking a short walk in Sembawang Park in the north or a little adventure in Labrador Park in the south. I may already started sounding like I'm marketing for National Parks now. Heh. Anyway, these are the things I realise about the convenience living in Singapore. You could go to such places within a short period of time. Our walk around Tiong Bahru, although wasn't quite a stroll in the park, it was nevertheless an enriching one. Thought provoking too. Down by the corner of a street, we saw a little lorry parked with a little banner appealing for witnesses to a crime committed in Lucky Chinatown. How much safe do we think we are? Even Singapore, a place never thought to be associated with such, has her version of brutality. Malaysia has her own share of dark tales and it's getting worse by the day. Just today, I read from this blog about a guy who got beaten up in the train till he was unconscious. When he woke up hours later, he realised he has been robbed. His jaw was broken and detached and is now wired shut, his eye socket fractured, sinuses shattered, nose broken, teeth broken.. That happened in downtown Los Angeles train system. What has happened to the world today? Has people today already started letting their emotions take over their actions. I think you realised in the picture below, in the banner, the beating in Chinatown actually happened on Valentine's Day. Was it an act out of jealousy? Or revenge? The heart is definitely stronger than the head these days. Conscience is definitely taking a backseat. Actions speak louder than words huh.
I noticed the community centres around Singapore have a common architecture, particularly this Tiong Bahru centre. Bright red bricks, crystalised windows with patterns and some marble wall finishing.
With a well-planned city such as Singapore, I was surprised that a less sophisticated parking payment system is used around HDB blocks. I agree that that there is less energy used to dispense parking coupons and it being a fool-proof system that avoids vandalism is a great idea but I think the hole-punching on the coupons for the parking time used is a bit undesireable. Anyway, that's just a very minor issue.
Walking from Tiong Bahru to Funan never seemed that a big deal that evening. The scenic route we took definitely showed quite a bit of intriguing sights before we stopped at McDonald's while waiting for Big Brother Vincent. There, I familiarised myself using the D70 on Ben to kill time.

It seems like whenever a big turning point comes knocking in my life, I tend to shy away from friends and my acquaintance. Could I be hiding any sign of weakness? Or I just want to avoid answering too many questions. Anyway, I didn't shut off myself from anyone because I was depressed nor was I trying to evade any questioning. I was just too engrossed in job searching in Singapore. And trying to keep myself focussed on some other matters as well. Everything else is good except one single hurdle I've to breakthrough. These days it is more difficult for a foreigner to start his first job in Singapore, especially when he has no experience in the industry, no Permanent Residence nor has he had any formal or partial education here. It is made worse, when recently, there is this regulation whereby if a person quits a job too frequently, or too early for another job, he may have difficulties getting a work permit the next time. With that, now I not only have to pick the right one for job advancement later in the years, I also have to make sure the pay package is good enough for 2 years, for me to send home at least some money to pay for my laptop installment. I'll set aside S$500 for that purpose. Next comes lodging. I will not stay at Ben's place for too long to avoid any form of friction with any of his family members. I want to maintain a good impression with them. So far, after more than 3 weeks here, things have been going well so I count my blessings. It seems like I might be heading for a good direction now. At least those phone calls from prospective employers and the second interview I'm to attend next Monday sounded promising to the point where I am convinced because I was told by one interviewing manager of a company I applied to, that if I manage it like I did in the first interview, I'd should have no problem sealing it with the "boss BOSS". On Sunday, Ben and I decided to take a good walk around Tiong Bahru, after a filling lunch at the temporary food square near the Tiong Bahru MRT station. While at that, both of us, equipped with our tools; he with his Nikon D2H and I with his Nikon D70, took a long, intensive walk in the quiet but charming Tiong Bahru neighbourhood, discovering quaint but no less interesting subjects before finally adjourning our walk in Chinatown. Can you believe that? *winks* Along the way, we came across brightly painted benches at a ball court, an injured pigeon taking a stroll, some life among the hedge and weeds, and some cats though I only took interest in one of them. We often overlook the beauty of things that surrounds us. They may be little things, ugly things, or just a big, old furniture. Some of these things have life. A history they have been through. A journey, never one could have imagined. Pre-production. Reproduction. Abuse. Love. Competition. Replacement. Decay. Scrap. They are all part of a cycle of life we are connected to in ways greater than the routine things you do every day. I understand there is this movie about the theory of "relativity". It started from someone killing a rat or something. And when the rat was disposed, it led to something else.. a chain reaction! Now, what's my point. I don't know. This confused, clueless ideologist just knocked off the theory of "relativity". *grins*

Helfen Sie Mir Bitte! by Vincent Lai Dare not walk Dare not talk Dare not quit Fear of messing it. It's unlike yesterday Tomorrow feels like today. The lights are weakening Is it really ending? The spark it used to be Now it's just fiery It burns all over me The pain is gone, now it's just empty. Isn't it an irony That you're unhappy Yet you can still breathe easy Like the day is still there, as if tomorrow is still problem free.

I was supposed to be recuperating from a bad flu and cough (and headache to a certain extent) since coming back from Hong Kong and Singapore. Tried to stay away from the Internet and writing. For a few days now, actually more than a week now, himwhite was coaxing me into updating my journal but I always never got to doing it. Well, tonight I relent. I came home from squash at about 2340H. Squash mates commented that I gained weight. "Your face puffed up a bit already," said one squash mate. So that's it! I need to get back into my usual sports activities. The pigging out in Hong Kong sure has added a few extra pounds to my face. Walking along the corridor leading to my apartment unit, I heard my neighbour's daughter playing piano as I stepped into the common compound of my apartment block. Everything was like usual; brother smoking in the living room while tapping on his laptop, chatting online. The TV flashing, with local TV station playing some boring local music programme. It was relatively a quiet night as it drew close to midnight. As I was chatting online with my regular MSN mates, I felt my table shook. Then a more consistent tremor affecting the walls, and shaking my bed gently. Even the lamp started swaying a bit. I was very concerned now. Then suddenly my brother yelled at me, "Hey, let's get the hell out of here. EARTHQUAKE!!" He pointed up to the ceiling fan which was shaking. I quickly grabbed my new laptop, told my brother to quickly grabbed his and ran out. Of course, I quickly locked the gates and walked to the emergency staircase. We knocked on our next door neighbour's door but no one answered. We shouted on top of our lungs, "Ms Chan, GET OUT!!". Mind you, we are on the 11th floor, the highest floor, so we were worried if our neighbours could escape should anything bad happens. We looked down from the common balcony. Many people were already gathering downstairs. Everyone was still calm when we walked down the staircase, with some exceptions who elbowed their way through the people walking downstairs. Panicked people around us were talking out loud among themselves, and many were driving their vehicles away from the area. My bro and I waited in the parking lot, calling our parents, our friends. I informed Ben about the incident. Concerned, he called and asked me about the whole situation. After what felt like an hour, we decided it should be safe to go back to our apartment. And here I am, safe and sound. I checked the news and found out that it was an 8.2 Richter scale earthquake in Sumatra, that led to the tremors in parts of Bangkok, Hat Yai and the west side of Malaysia, even Singapore. Let's pray everyone affected by the tremor and the earthquake will be safe.

Got into Singapore in the wee hours of Saturday. 0300H, in front of Golden Mile Complex. Took a cab and headed straight to rendezvous with Ben at his office in Orchard Road. Picked him up at the taxi place, before proceeded back to his place in Bukit Batok. Hours later, actually many significant hours later, when the sun was really up, we got up and got ready for the day's activities. I earlier planned to go to the Career Fair in Suntec City. Met up with my KL squash buddy, Tommy who was also in town for the fair. He was there earlier and when we met up, he was planning to go for his lunch with his other friend, Jeff. After an hour's talk at the lobby lounge, I decided to check out the fair. Told them I'd meet up with them at Millennia Walk if I managed to finish before 6. True to my prediction, I finished very fast. Nothing much at the fair. More than 60% of the fair was represented by universities and institutions. And the jobs offered by prospective companies wanted Singapore citizens and permanent residents. Anyway, while I was there, took some pictures of Suntec City Exhibition Centre with the SONY DSC Cyber-shot M1 I borrowed from my cousin for the Hong Kong trip. The pictures churned out by the camera look good. But my only complaint about the camera model is that it's not so hand-held friendly.
Went to meet up with Tommy (picture below), Jeff and this time, his bf Gary (picure below) at Coffee Club in Millennia Walk. Sat there, chatted a bit before I left for Peninsula Plaza to get ink cartridge for Ben. Later at night, Ben and I (bottom-most picture) had dinner at TCC with his god-brother, Clement and a mystery date.. hehe.. and that's another story.

What can 2 men do, in a room full of blue? The answer is not what I think you think it is because what you think is not the only thing I think you can do. Mouthful answer huh. eheheheheeee... Last Sunday, while I was working a bit in front of my PC, with Ben sleeping right behind me, I decided to make use of his camera. Shooting objects in my room. Boy, I seemed really bored huh. Anyway, I wasn't.

I had a really strange dream today. i was driving on a highway, taking a turn into a road that leads to a hilly place. a friend was beside me. my best friend, daniel. going uphill, we came to a halt when we saw a group of people jogging down. mostly school girls. with some older folks accompanying them. must be the girls' teachers. we decided to turn back. suddenly the whole scene flashed forward to the part where i was rollerblading down the steep road. by then, daniel has disappeared. as i was rollerblading down, i made some skillful flips and jumps and rode on really quickly. at one corner, i couldn't control myself. i fell down. embarrassed, so i stood up quickly, removed the gear and ran down barefeet through the group of girls. I accidentally bump into this pretty looking girl on my right. and guess what, i squeezed her breast. and the weird part is, i had intended to do that, whether it was by accident or not. she wouldn't accept my apology. she must have sensed it was deliberate. she looked like those active, no-frills and sharp witted kind of girl. she was loud and made a fuss and threatened to report to the police. i reaffirmed and apologised to her it was accident, because I was running and therefore not logical and doesn't make sense if I sexually harrased her. one male teacher encouraged her to report to the police. another lady teacher, who saw the whole incident from the point i fell till the point i bumped into her told the girl to drop it and explained to her that she saw that i accidentally touched her when i bumped into her. the girl wouldn't give in. we were suddenly in the police station, and the police didn't believe her, with the lady teacher's report favouring me. *grins* I got up after that. *winks* I really don't understand that dream. How could I have that sort of feeling? Evil.

Taking a break here to write an update and e-mail. Earlier, I made use of my brother's basic point-and-shoot, 2MP digital camera. Took some pictures and edited a bit on Photoshop because they really looked sucky. As you can see, the main pic is of two cartoon-rooster decorative cards that my brother stuck to the door last night. Well, if you haven't realised it by now, the Lunar New Year is just hours away and this year, is known as The Year of The Cock or Rooster, whichever you prefer. Mum was preparing the food for the reunion dinner the whole day. Our concept of reunion dinner comprises of one whole steamed chicken, a plate of oysters + sea cucumber in dark sauce, stir-fried prawns, a plate of blanched broccoli and a bowl of pork-belly soup each. Just a while ago, mum was chopping and cutting the steamed chicken in the kitchen. I remember a year ago, when we were still staying in our old house in Sea Park; our dog, Whiskey would come close and sniff whenever mum did that on a block of wood cutting board. And he would try stealing scraps of meat when mum was not looking.
This year, staying at my parents' apartment in Puchong, a lot of things have changed. Now we don't have prayer's altars anymore. I am secretly glad by that because I never liked it when dad had so many prayer's altars in the house and the house would be choking with thick smell of incense and joss stick that would hurt my eye and made me sneeze so much whenever I was home. A smaller place now. But we have a nicer view now. Heheh.. On a good day, we could see Genting Highlands clearly. Those creamy white coloured hotel blocks.
As compared to when we had a house where we could have some trees, lots of bright coloured blossoming bush and a little padang [field in Malay] for the dog to run on in the garden, now it's a mere rows of potted plants on the balcony.
Since last evening, my brother came back from Singapore. His work with OSIM seems to have made him fatter, chubbier and supposedly more prosperous. He got a wireless router just so we could share the broadband. Took a little time off last night to configure the settings so that no one else on the block could piggyback or share our Internet connection. It seems like a blessing, because my brother and I seem to talk more now, albeit it was done mostly via MSN. We hardly talk much throughout our teenage years because we always ended up arguing. Not a mere 5 mins into talking, we had ended up talking elbow to elbow. Heh.
It's almost time for dinner. Here I want to wish everyone a good holiday celebration and to the Chinese community, a very happy Chinese (Lunar) New Year. May this year be a good year.

I'm battling with my own conscience. I feel so, so bad and so miserable that I don't know if I should go on being nice. Can someone tell me where to draw the line to doing good? I've been doing the chauffeuring, driving my cancer-stricken uncle to the hospital quite frequently (for at least twice a week) for the past 2 months (or is it longer, I lost count) for his medical check-ups and recently, his chemotherapy and radiotherapy sessions. Worse, I've been made full use by my aunt and my mum to run some errands sometimes. And this morning, at 7.30am in the morning, in the midst of my peaceful sleep, I got a call from my uncle that I have to drive him to the hospital right away for his sessions. In my mind, I was like, "What the f**k!". But I regained my composure by being calm and told him I will pick him up soon, within and hour. And he told me, from today onwards, he has to go for his sessions everyday. And asked me if I could fetch him everyday and tell him the days I'm not free. Frankly speaking, I'm not free everyday. This should explain my infrequent posts. Here I am, trying to prepare for my upcoming exam which will happen a week after Chinese New Year's day. On top of that, I still have one project to finish. I feel like giving up on the former. But that would mean absolute inconvenience to him and his kids. Yes, his sons. He has 2 sons. Older than I am and working. Suddenly it hit me. Shouldn't his sons be doing all these? Urrghhh... should I still be a part of it?

Ain't this such a beautiful place? Can anyone guess where this is? No prize for guessing it correctly. And you do not need to look very far. Can you believe it is also a country by itself? And it sustains itself mostly through tourism. :) *Disclaimer: I did not take the photos. And I do not know who is the photographer.

// We are creatures sometimes. You can hide it, be in touch with it, but don't be it. // The Creature In Me by Vincent Lai lying next to an ill, medieval monitor overwhelmed; choking smell of burnt rubbish fills my poorly ventilated nostrils. looking at the window imagining; some lousy neighbour an ignorant old man. topless, tanned body his wife touches no more greying hair, sagging breasts protrudding belly with some hair. in his torn denim pants standing barefeet on dry earth his cracked heels exposed to dioxinated matter. i felt no pity to his state for a moment i thought i wasn't human for that split second i wasn't i wasn't who i portrayed to be i wasn't that same old me i was a filthy creature i was all but me I was.

Last weekend, legolas79 was asking if anyone would want to join him for a stage play, Spring Singing where he featured pictures of some actors in his journal entry. Well, I have a confession to make. Remember my previous trip to Singapore in October which I didn't quite blog about? On the last day of my trip, I sort of assisted Cobalt aka Dios Vincoy Jr. in his promo shoot for the cast and team of Spring Singing. Sort of, because I think I didn't quite help much as he almost single-handedly managed everything himself, except for holding the reflector and fetching some equipment. We got up very early in the morning, on a Sunday; I believe. Took a cab to this bungalow, which by now I have forgotten its location. I swear. *winks* A huge house by itself, complete with a nice swimming pool att he corner of their yard. We were greeted by the production's set designer, Goh Boon Teck and the producer, Lily Leong and the host of the house. As we placed the equipment in the living room, we were greeted warmly by two of the house pets, a Schnauzer and the other one I forgot its breed. Very cute and friendly dogs albeit they were quite always sniffing you out for food. Minutes later, the director, Mr Jeremiah Choy came in by cab. And slowly, but surely, the stage actors finally arrived on their own. Loud. Noisy bunch of gay men. Shall update more later [Read Spring Singing Part II] as I need to rush to college. P.S: In the meantime, here's a preview of pictures I took in the duration of the shoot.

Finally reached Singapore, but not without an incident. Heh. Everything was smooth (excluding the very bad traffic congestion in Johor Bahru all the way to the Singapore Immigration Checkpoint), until I reached the Customs Check. One anal retentive female, 30-something Malay officer had suspicions about my bag contents. The other 2 male officers told her it's ok but she was being such a bitch and she asked me if I brought in CDs. I nodded and showed her where they are. And boy! She asked me to get into a room, and behind the closed door, she asked if I had any clue that I'm having something illegal in my possession. I had no idea. She said that one of the DVDs (Ben's) is illegal. Must be the print on the DVD which showed a man on top of another. That's a Wong Kar Wai's HAPPY TOGETHER movie and I told her that it doesn't belong to me and I'm returning it to my friend in Singapore and she said it's an R(A) film. She instructed me to destroy it in front of her and another officer. I was embarrassed. She logged the DVD details in a book, with my passport details. "No shit, this ain't gonna be good!" Now, I'm here.. safe and sound. And realised I forgot to bring my Singapore SIM card and so I cannot be reached on the phone. If any of you want to contact me, call Ben's number at +65 9009 9875 or text me at this number +65 9079 4766. P.S: I did pee on my pants ( IN THE SINGAPORE CHECKPOINT TOILET CUBICLE, after being cleared by the Customs ), but it happened only because I didn't aim nicely.

Tonight, I got back from playing squash and I chanced upon a blog that is supposedly of the director of the acclaimed Malaysian movie, SEPET; Yasmin Ahmad. In one of her entries, she ranted about that recent film being banned in Malaysia. Imagine, a film made in Malaysia being banned here in our homeland. Reacting to the entry she made, I posted a short comment. Here goes: - - - - - - - - I'm not surprised that the Malaysia Censorship Board IS so shallow-minded, and probably to many points, absurd, and inconsistent in their screening policy. I was absolutely embarrassed when my fellow Singaporean friends asked me about Sepet and I could just tell them I'd not seen it. And it was only recently when I watched it that I realised that this is in fact one beautiful, commendable film and it is so well-received there that everyone thought, "This comes as a surprise from a country such as Malaysia". How would you respond to that remark? I'm terribly sorry that our film industry is so stunted by these regulations that fend off any sign of creativity. And this, is a proof that the people in the board must be from some stunted upbringing that they failed to realise the artistic value of a film. Yet they could accept those mundane love-hate movies that only appeal to a particular level of the society. Hence the failure of our country's cinematic development. - - - - - - - - Reasons Sepet did not make it to the golden screens in Malaysia. (Get ready to laugh!) 1. The Malay girl (lead actress) did not make any attempt to convert her Chinese boyfriend (into Islam). 2. The scene where Adibah, Ida and Amani were lovingly combing each other's hair by the staircase, was encouraging Malay women to go back to their bad old habit of picking each other's lice! "At the end of it all, they said that we shouldn't blame them for the cuts, because they represented the rakyat (which means citizens). And that they had shown our film to some members of "the rakyat", and their verdict was to ban Sepet." - Yasmin Ahmad.
